snippet: At the height of the crack era, teachers pitched education as the border between those who would prosper and those who would be fed to the great hydra of prison, teenage pregnancy and murder.
abstract: Op-Ed article by Ta-Nehisi Coates reflects on his middling triumphs and spectacular failures as a schoolboy during the height of the crack era, contrasting his experience with that of his 11-year-old son in a progressive private school; observes that education remains the dividing line for black children between a life of prosperity or one of despair.
lead_paragraph: At the height of the crack era, teachers pitched education as the border between those who would prosper and those who would be fed to the great hydra of prison, teenage pregnancy and murder.
